column2: 0 Born in Duanesburg, NY to Alton and Ruth Roe
Feelings of mistreatment by parents; spent most of childhood alone; claimed parents
6-23 would lock her in her room at times for up to a day; said her father used to hit her with
a flyswatter; her aunt used to tell her that she was an unplanned and unwanted child
20-21 Marybeth met Joe Tinning on a blind date
24 Barbara, Marybeth’s first child, is born
27 Joseph, Marybeth’s second child, is born
29 Marybeth’s father, Alton Roe, dies of a sudden heart attack at the age of 54
29 Jennifer, Marybeth’s third child, is born
Jennifer dies, only 8 days old, from hemorrhagic meningitis and multiple brain
Joseph dies after being rushed to the hospital; death attributed to cardiopulmonary
29 Marybeth rushes Barbara to the hospital, claiming she had gone into convulsions
Barbara dies, after being in a comatose state for several hours; death attributed to
29 Marybeth begins work at Flavorland as a waitress
Marybeth calls the Schenectady Department of Social Services, expressing her interest
29-30 Tinning family took in a foster child, Robert, until January 1973
Tinning family took in a foster child, Linda, but she was soon sent back to Social
Services when Marybeth became pregnant with Timothy
31 Timothy, Marybeth’s fourth child, is born
31 Marybeth takes Timothy to the emergency room, but he is already dead; death

column3: attributed to Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
Marybeth and Joe argued over money on numerous occasions

Marybeth poisons her husband with a lethal dose of phenobarbital, but he wasconvinced that it was an attempted suicide on his own part; Marybeth admits tostealing money from Carol, her sister-in-law; Marybeth agrees to see a psychiatrist, butescapes from the hospital without her husband, husband’s brother, or Carol knowing
Marybeth reports to the police that her home had been burglarized, although it waslater concluded that Marybeth most likely staged the robbery herself
Marybeth admitted to a coworker that she was pregnant again, told her not to tellanyone, and told the coworker that “God had told her to kill this one, too”
Nathan, Marybeth’s fifth child, is born
Nathan dies in the car while out with Marybeth
Marybeth adopts her sixth child, Michael, shortly after he is born
Mary Frances, Marybeth’s seventh child, is born
Marybeth rushes Mary Frances to the hospital, unconscious; Mary Frances is revived,hospital reports “aborted SIDS”
Marybeth returns to the hospital with Mary Frances in full cardiac arrest; she isrevived, but has irreversible brain damage
Mary Frances dies, after Marybeth finally agrees to take her off of life support
Jonathan, Marybeth’s eighth child, is born
Jonathan dies, after being kept on life support in Albany, NY for four weeks
Michael’s behavior and demeanor are back to normal. The previous week, Michaelhad fallen down the stairs and hit his head, Marybeth took him to the hospital
Marybeth takes Michael to the doctor’s office when he won’t wake up, he dies
Marybeth and Joe move in with Joe’s parents in Duanesburg for 11 months; Marybethdoes a variety of jobs, participates in church life, and volunteers as an ambulancedriver
Marybeth and Joe Tinning buy a trailer in Duanesburg, NY, but it soon catches fireand is destroyed; suspicions pointed to Marybeth as the culprit
Marybeth and Joe Tinning move back to Schenectady
Marybeth stops volunteering at the ambulance corps after a first aid box was foundnear her home, with stolen contents from the Duansburg ambulance corps inside
Marybeth begins driving a school bus for Dubb Transportation until June 1985
Tami Lynne, Marybeth’s ninth child, is born
Tami Lynne dies from being smothered
The Tinning family is visited by Betsy Mannix, of Schenectady County’s Departmentof Social services, and Bob Imfeld, of the Schenectady Police Department, regardingthe death of Tami Lynne
Reverend Roger Daly visits the Tinning residence and agrees to conduct Tami Lynne’sfuneral
Tami Lynne’s funeral is held
Marybeth Tinning meets with Betsy Mannix again; appears overly concerned withBetsy’s perception of her during their previous meeting

The NY state police’s Bureau of Criminal Investigation, essentially the first unit offorensic science and investigation in the state, was contacted to aid in the investigationof Tami Lynne Tinning’s death

Marybeth and Joe Tinning were separately taken to the Schenectady police departmentfor questioning regarding the death of Tami Lynne; it was here that she confessed tothe murders of Tami Lynne, Timothy, and Nathan; Marybeth was arrested and chargedwith the murder of her daughter, Tami Lynne Tinning
Marybeth Tinning makes her $100,000 bail and is released from custody until her trialdate
After a six-week long trial, the jury returned with a verdict of guilty of murder in thesecond degree
11 weeks after her trial, Marybeth is sentenced to 20 years to life in prison at BedfordHills prison for women
Marybeth’s appeal was denied by the NY State Supreme Court’s Appellate Division
Marybeth was denied parole
Marybeth was denied parole
Marybeth was denied parole
Marybeth is up for parole again
